##  Code Chunk Explained a Bit More

The code chunks will include all your code, you can click Insert a new code chunk to your top right.
Each chunk should have its own name. You can add a name after the first reserved word which
refers to the language your code is in, this will be lowercase r for any R code. Follow the chunk name by
a comma, for names try avoiding dashes, if there is an error with your code the error message will
let you know which chunk has an issue. To evaluate, run the code, you will need to type `eval = TRUE`,
if you do not want to run this code when you render the document change to `FALSE`. If you want to 
print your code in the slides add `echo = TRUE`.

```{r, eval = FALSE, echo=TRUE}     

library(network)
```

## Components

### Alerts & Cross-refs {#sec-crossref}

To emphasize specific words or text, you can:

- Use the default `.alert` class, e.g. [important note]{.alert}.
- Use the `.fg` class for custom colour, e.g. [important note]{.fg style="--col: #e64173"}.
- Use the `.bg` class for custom background, e.g. [important note]{.bg style="--col: #e64173"}.

To cross-reference, you have several options, for example:

- Beamer-like `.button` class provided by this theme, e.g. [[Appendix]{.button}](#sec-appendix)
- Quarto's native cross-ref syntax, e.g., "See @sec-appendix."

## Quarto allows you to have different tabs

::: {.panel-tabset}

#### (a) Wave 1 
```{r echo=TRUE}
low_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.1)    # provide your own parameters
length(low_prevalence) 
head(low_prevalence)
```

#### (b) Wave 2
```{r echo=TRUE}
moderate_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.4)    # provide your own parameters
length(moderate_prevalence) 
head(moderate_prevalence)
```

#### (c) Wave 3
```{r echo=TRUE}
high_prevalence <- rbinom(n = 100, size = 10, prob = 0.6)     # provide your own parameters
length(high_prevalence) 
head(high_prevalence)
```
::: 

## Summary for Results

```{r echo=TRUE}

library(psych)
library(knitr)

summary_samples <- rbind(low_smoking = describe(low_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         moderate_smoking = describe(moderate_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75) ), 
                         high_smoking = describe(high_prevalence,quant=c(.25,.75)) )

summary_samples <- summary_samples[,c("mean","se", "sd", "min", "Q0.25", "median", "Q0.75", "max")]

kable(summary_samples)

```

You can wrap LaTeX code in $x$, for any symbols.
You can dynamically refer to a variable output in line, like the standard deviation `{r} round(sd(low_prevalence),2)`

Or the value of the median to describe your data  `{r} median(low_prevalence)`

## Line Highlighting

-   Highlight specific lines for emphasis
-   Incrementally highlight additional lines

``` {.python code-line-numbers="4-5|7|10"}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(subplot_kw={'projection': 'polar'})
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()
```

::: footer
Learn more: [Line Highlighting](https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs/#line-highlighting)
:::
